												Painkiller is an PC designed Action FPS game where you take the role of Daniel, a person who goes to purgatory after an car accident. Daniel must fight his way if he wants to get to heaven since the hell's warriors are attempting to take Daniel into hell. What you heard, is also what Painkiller is all about, killing. You will be mauling down hordes of hundreds of different enemies in different location ranging from Icy Bridge to Abandoned Mansion with loonies in it to Trophical Palaces of Persian regions or midevil times Castles and soforth.. Modernday set Harbour Docks. Almost all of these maps feature completely new set of enemies, so there is quite alot of enemy variety.Painkiller offers very beautiful and badass cold feeling aesthetic, extremely badass metal soundtrack and more mood athmosphere creating ambience music. You have ability to bunnyhop in the game which will accelerate your max movement speed a bit compared to default walking. Painkiller is the kinda game where you're recommended to use bunnyhopping or else the enemies will surround you quite fast and kill you. Game has secrets which are mainly accessed via bunnyhop done trickjumps of different kinds. So keep your eyes open for those since they can provide you general currency (system used to access game's temporary bonus gameplay abilities such as even faster movement speed) or health/armor/ammo pickups.In Painkiller, health is scarce if you're playing on the hardest difficulty, Trauma. There's only couple 25-50hps and or 100hps basically available for you per level + armors. Nightmare difficulty (second hardest) offers imo the most balanced system, because here the enemies will leave a 1hp soulpoint behind which will spawn from the dead enemy after couple secs and eventually will disappear if not taken. These souls are used to access the game's Rage Mode too. Rage mode is where you will turn into this temporary invulnerability mode where you have only one kinda attack present but trust me, you gonna be glad it's there because this is not an easy game :)Guns in this game all have an alternate fire and since it's usually even completely different compared to primary fire, you have got quite many guns in here. Guns go from Painkiller (spinning circular saw of death and a beam based laser), Quad Barrel Shotgun with Freeze bullets, Minigun with Rocketlauncher, Stakegun with Grenades (can be comboed, nade2stake=long distance explosive fire), Lightningun with Shurikens and so forth.. to Flamethrower.Level design of Painkiller is more of new school really but the illusion works here. The game is based on linear level design form where you never really have multiple choices of where to go but instead these combat arenas which are fairly large and always do connect to the next area through only one passageway. You need to kill all the enemies in the room before door is opened up for you to proceed to the next area. There is no keycard hunts in this either. So if you're looking for your classic Doom experience, well.. you're not gonna find it other than the classic no weaponlimits enemy killing with fast movement speed. Other than that, Painkiller is very different kinda game but still very fun challenging.You can conf this game quite much and do that either through the game options or from the .ini file in the main dir.PAINengine deserves a special shout out for the completely raw mouse input. This game literally has as good feeling non-accelerated input as Quake 3. Positives  Fastpaced and challenging PC FPS gameplay Athmosphere Music (EXTREMELY BADASS) Skillbased movement mechanics Hard secrets Totally raw mouse input Editor support and good developer guides for it Arena Shooter genre multiplayer (Quake 3/Unreal Tournament) Negatives  Total linearity Doors that open only once room is cleaned of enemies Some bossfights are borderline of being un-fair Expansion Pack lacks on quality compared to maingame

												Painkiller: Black Edition combines in itself original Painkiller and it's expansion pack Battle Out Of Hell, that adds new campaign with new elements, including two weapons that you can then get in original Painkiller campaign. Though, maybe you aren't supposed to, but you still can. Painkiller was a bit FPS title that came out in 2004 and was considered as old-school. It also has multiplayer competive mode.Black Edition is pretty much same as Gold Edition, by the way. Just was difference in package, CDs versus DVD.Oh, and it contains video extras.Technically, this old game still works. Supposed to. Sure, it doesn't support multi-core processor, so a little older computers will have trouble here and there, unless it's old enough to have just one strong core. Progress is a funny thing. Surprisingly, it supports widescreen resolution. Not HUD parts, but still.Also, GameSpy service is dead, don't bother installing that.As for multiplayer community part, well, it's probably not exactly alive. It wasn't so much active to begin with, just getting small deathmatch here and there. But since Gamespy closed down, the in-game Internet Server Browser doesn't work anymore. You can still connect directly, but it still hits on community, you know.So, Painkiller. Big deal. It was like a modern take on old-school shooter. Well, at least "kill stuff" part of old-school shooter, for it threw key-hunting, switches and mazes out of window. Instead main game process goes like: get to checkpoint, have health restored, get closed and kill everything, repeat. Not to say that levels don't have secrets, but you will get to fully explore level only when you are almost done and exit appeared. Then all the doors will automatically open. It still kinda feels weird though.You will get to explore the setting of Purgatory and Hell, with Hell not being just "it's red everywhere", more of little nightmare settings. You will get to shoot at things in cemetery, graveyards, modern opera houses and military base. While also sometimes getting rare FMV cutscene that explains part of storyline. Interesting stuff, kinda.The game was quite modern for it's time. And "modern" part of 2004 comes not only with graphics, but with obessivness over physics. And so this game occasionally throws some physics part, like falling light at Opera House or shaking bridge at Catacombs, just for sake of having them there. Because physics were cool novel thing and everybody was going crazy over them. Not that I complain, it gets creative at times. Making things flip onto wall with shotgun is fun, with ragdolls and all.Oh yea. And freaking Stakegun.Let's just say that when game came out, everybody was like "OMG STAKEGUN 10/10". It really was satificatory and novel thing as successful stake hit would stick enemy's body part to the wall, with every other part hanging down. People may not care nowdays, but back then it was making everybody go hard. Unless you managed to miss it between enemy's arm and torso. Because having collision same as model itself was novel too. And that's why good designers still use collision boxes when it comes to projectiles, can't let rocket miss between legs.As for core gameplay, well, it tries to be good. And mostly succeeds. It keeps throwing a good variety of mosnters at you in small encounters. Some melee ones, some ranged ones. Some can even do additional stuff on each other. You also got a wide arsenal of weapons. Each one of them has two firing modes that use different ammo and since you can switch between weapons instantly, then it's like having 10 types of attacks at once. Almost. Read manual to learn more, there are some interesting combo.Then again, who needs stakegun's grenadelauncher mode, when you got minigun's rocketlauncher mode that uses same ammo? And who needs submachine gun when minigun shoots accurate anyway?But then, game is not afraid to be cheap either. Usual hitscan enemies are included. No, not bakers, those are more interesting. Just things that don't feel too fair.And this is where I shall tell you of bosses. They are divided into two categories: good ones and cheap ones. Good ones are awesome. Huge and epic and proper. Cheap ones are gimmicky as hell. And really, there are some horrible bosses. For example, the first miniboss you will meet looks no different from tougher enemies that you encountered before in same level, so you will unload your whole ammunition into him before realizing that you have to be "smart" and shoot at boards on the ceiling for no reason. Final boss of expansion pack is a downer, with you being forced to take damage. Even boss battle of the 4th chapter forces you to take fall damage.Another thing to note is inclusion of bunnyhopping. It's not bug anymore, it's a full feature that you are really encouraged to use. Just keep pressing "jump" while going in direction you want, and you will speed up. It's very controllable and you can go in any direction without losing speed, so it's awesome.Also, I should note music. It can be clearly divided into two parts: awesome metal/fight music and ambient one. I am sure that fight music of the first level will get stuck in your head for a while. Classic. But then, there is ambient track written for each level, which is more effort than you would expect. It playes when you aren't fighting and just explore level before next checkpoint fight and sets quite a different mood. Like two opposite sides in same game. Boss music is weak though.Game also tries to do it's own thing, with souls, gold and Tarot Cards. Fallen enemies dissapear into soul after few seconds, that you can collect to gain 1hp. There are also some rare bigger health pickups in the game, but your main source will be checkpoints which restore you to the fullest. But if you collect 66 of them, then you will temporary transform into demon, which means having black-white-red color pallete, invincibility and ability to gib things with a click of a mouse.And then you will notice that there is gold rolling around on the floor quite often, from chests and gibs, that you can collect. What is it for? Well, as you noticed from stats, each level has additional objective, like "kill all enemies" (meaning "find all secrets", really) or "use only stakegun", that will give you tarot card upon beating stage. You can have two silver and three golden Tarot Cards at once. Setting them in inventory costs gold. Silver cards give passive bonuses, while golden cards can be activated once per level.So, errrr, yea, gold, souls and Tarot Cards is something you can ignore, really. I don't feel that they are important enough, objectives for cards aren't always fun either.And yes, game has multiplayer. It even enjoyed competive scene for a short time after release. It was nicely designed, with few gamemodes. One of them is related to rocketjumping in low-gravity. But the only thing I got to play is Deathmatch, community isn't alive enough right now for other types. It's quite fast-paced and makes use of few weapons, even though the fast stake will still most likely instakill. Easy bunnyhop really helps to make chasing more exciting and levels are well done, looking nice overall but not having details to take away your attention, just you and enemies. So, yes. Stakegun/10. An interesting "old-school" FPS, which is more similiar to Serious Sam. That tries to do it's own things too. And well, was real nice for 2004.

												Truly well crafted shooters that are clear about the direction they want to take are few and far between. Painkiller is a game of a now dying breed. It isn't saturated by combinations of gameplay mechanics and quick time events. There are no escort missions or timed sequences. There is however a wall of "meat" between you and your inevitable antagonist which you brave with a variety of surprising combinations of weapons. There are a few things of note in Painkiller. Firstly its masterfully designed environments. In no other shooter have I been as immersed in a setting of an abandoned dock or streets of war torn Stalingrad, the musical accompaniment of which goes a long way to help those locals come alive. The second and a most entertaining aspect to me personally were the gargantuan boss battles. Structured as a classical first person shooter as Painkiller is, you can be assured that at the end of every level there will be a phantasmagorical boss for you to slay. In any other game any of those encounters could easily qualify as the end game culmination. Which if you are persistent enough to reach you will guaranteed be astounded by. Lastly a worthy of note mechanic of tarot cards and soul collecting makes for interesting gameplay scenarios. I will not go much into this mechanic as I am sure those new to the game will appreciate discovering its benefits and multiple combination on their own. Needless to say however it is the icing on the cake that is Painkiler. In summary if you are searching for a well crafted and orchestrated FPS shooter experience that is as straightforward as it is entertaining, look no further as Painkiller is most reassuringly a game for you.

Painkiller is an awesome shooter. Featuring Quake -like mechanics like bunny hopping and auto-reloading, a cool purgatory designed world, and awesome metal music, Painkiller  is an adrenaline rush all the way through, and you'll enjoy every second of the showers of blood and death you bring on your enemies across ~20 levels. The story is fairly forgettable but works, about on par with most shooters like this.One of the best parts about this game is its heavy use of the Havok physics engine. Not only are environments destructible, but the game has dozens of Secrets that require cool physics puzzles to figure out. You also get to do this with the game's bosses, which are both fun to fight and have puzzles of their own. Tarot cards add a lot of cool effects and replayability to the game as well.For the Black edition you also get the Expansion pack Battle Out of Hell, which adds another 10 levels and continues the story past the original ending. It's just as much fun as the initial game, and features new weapons.People Can Fly made an awesome game, and it's not surprising that they eventually went on to make Bulletstorm. If you've ever wondered how People Can Fly broke into gaming, now you can (and should) find out.

												I find it to be a fun game for its time, with smooth and intuitive gameplay that rewards the player for putting effort into mastering it. Unfortunately, many of the "innovative" additions to the gameplay feel out of place, such as the psychic mode where you click to blow up a bunch of enemies with some pseudo-angelic/demon powers that don't really feel fun or rewarding. All it does is distract the flow of the game, to the point where I wish there was a setting to disable it. Then there's the Tarot card mechanic, which also feels badly implemented - as the effects are either too strong or too weak depending on the stage and the card in question. Furthermore, you have to go out of your way to find them, which sometimes includes doing outrageously time-consuming tasks that take away from the fun of the game, such as killing every single enemy or finding every coin on a level. Considering how absolutely huge some of the stages are, it really kills the pacing of the game. It's only worth getting if you're a big fan of the classic Shooter genre, and even then you're probably not going to like it for the same reasons you like, say, Doom or Quake. It's a niche game for a niche audience, and feels like a transitional game between classic and modern FPS. It never managed to find its identity, and the horrendous expansions didn't help it any.

												Zero Punctuation usually preaches this game is a highlight of shooters and puts it on a pedestal for its fun shooty gameplay. I'm interested in playing cult classics since they tend to be good and I'm always open to playing a classic people say is good so what do I think?Story:It's bad. It's very bad and one of the worst stories I've ever played in a shooter. Sure it provides context on whats going one but its so boring and I didn't care. They just kept talking and talking about things I didn't understand and they even try to do a twist which was poorly done cause we barely seen the elements that were involved in said twist.Gameplay:But who needs story when we can tear people to shred with a lawnmower. This is a kind of shooter I heard of but never played before: the arena shooter. In this game you don't explore the levels to find keys to open doors and switches while killing everything in the way, you have to paint the arena you're in red with the blood of every enemy in the room before a door opens for you to give the next room a new coat of paint. I was actually a bit surprise at first with all the enemies that tried to kill you at once that I haven't seen since Final Doom. To kill these goons you have about five weapons which is pretty small but are technically two guns in one. You lawnmower that can fir its claw and make a deadly but weak laser beam to you, the shotgun that can freeze enemies to make them more vulnerable, the rocket launcher that has a minigun and Yahtzee's favourite: the gun that shoot shuirkens and lightning. My favourite is the one that shoots giant stakes and is like a sniper rifle but it has a arch to when fired which is pretty cool.And finally I thought the first and last boss were bad but the ones in between were pretty good, actually getting me to observe whats going on and seeing if I did something right. Yes, there is a card system but I never used it and the special power you get after a certain amount of souls was powerful but has a similar problem with FF9's trance system where you might accidentally get a soul after a fight and you might not have enough time to use it before it wears off. I will admit the gameplay can get repetitive after a while. but...Presentation:If there's one thing I can say about Painkiller is that it's varied. Sure at first you'll be in a dark grave yard fighting skeleton minions and old ladies and then in a grey cathedral against robed demons. And after the first chapter, you're in a opera house fighting ninja or going though an abandon asylum or fighting gimp commandos and Nazi zombies in a train station. It keeps changing where you're fighting in every level that you won't get bored of the visuals.Music is pretty fun too. Not that memorable but it will get your blood pumping with its metal tracks and it keeps blaring means you still have work to do.And as for the cutscene, the visuals suck and the voice actors have nothing to work with.Verdict:So yeah, just like Yahtzee said. Sometimes all you need is to shoot someone. In a safe environment. Don't want to be giving people ideas.7/10
